sentence: zilam henek-ê xwe bi jin-ê di-k-e
glosses_en: man joke-EZ.PL self with woman-OBL.F PRS-do.IPFV-3SG
back_translation_en: ‘The man makes fun of the woman.’
comms_internal: CV. The X argument is classified as “SBJ.TR” because in the Past tense, X bears the OBL marker (visible in the case of non-masculine nouns), cf. “zarok-ên din henek-ê xwe pê kir-in” [child-EZ.PL other joke-EZ.PL self in.him do.PFV-3PL] ‘Other children made fun of him’ (bi + ‘him’ > pê).

The X argument is encoded by OBL regardless of the tense. The second argument triggers agreement on the copula. Alternative to this structure is the structure where X is expressed as an NP-internal modifier (and such a construction does not meet the inclusion criteria), cf. “tirimbêl-ek-e jinik-ê heye” [car(F)-INDEF-EZ.F woman-OBL.F EXST.SG] ‘The woman has a car.’, lit. “the woman’s car exists” (the agreement is also trigger by the possessee). The rules governing the competition between the two structures (cf. min X heye [1SG.OBL X EXST] vs. Или X min heye [X-EZ 1SG.OBL heye]) are not fully clear. Probably, a dialectal difference.

back_translation_en: ‘The man is looking for his keys.’
comms_internal: In this example, there is a mismatch between the morphological pattern of the verb (intr) and its argument-encoding pattern involving SBJ.TR. The X argument is classified as “SBJ.TR” because in the Past tense, X does not bear the OBL marker (visible in the case of non-masculine nouns), cf. “jinik-ê duh tevahiy-a roj-ê li miftey-ên xwe geri-ya” [woman-OBL.F yesterday whole-EZ.F day-OBL.F key-EZ.PL own look.PFV.SG-PERF] ‘Yesterday the woman looked for her keys all day.’
CV. Interesting pattern: CV with an internal object (“paint”) that nevertheless takes one more direct object.

Same as 119, 129. The X argument is classified as “SBJ.TR” because in the Past tense, X does not bear the OBL marker (visible in the case of non-masculine nouns), cf. “jinik-ê berê ji mêrik hez di-kir” [woman-OBL.F earlier from man love PRS-do.PFV.SG] ‘The woman used to love the man.’ Alternative is the transitive construction with the same predicate “hez kirin”, cf. “Pîrek-ê berê hez mêr di-kir” [woman-OBL.F before love man PRS-do.PFV.SG] ‘The woman used to love the man’. Dictionaries agree that both patterns do exist.

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
comms_internal: CV. The pattern is not fully clear. The Y component can be analyzed as NP-internal modifier, but the noun ‘attack’ is not in the ezaphe form. There is no ezafe marker on êrîşî, but some nouns behave like that according to Kurdish grammars, as also confirmed by Haig’s analysis of similar patterns. Arguably, X is expressed as SBJ.TR here (but, strictly seaking, a past tense sentence is needed to confir this). Sometime in the future it is desirable to check whether “masîgir-ek-î” part can be displaced anywhere away from “êrîşî”.

comms: Non-verbal predicate.
comms_internal: For Nikita: check the agreement pattern in this sentence using plural nouns. Does the verb agree with “euro”, “lacking” or “man”? Regardless of the answer “SBJ.INTR_NOM” is an impossible label for the pattern, as we do not have “NOM” as the status. Maybe the man is underlyingly OBL (use the noun like “woman”)? If not, is it NP-internal (as part of the NP headed by “kêmî”)? If not again, then it should probably be reinterpreted as BARE, see the new version of the annotation_principles file.

CV. The X argument is classified as “SBJ.TR” because in the Past tense, X bears the OBL marker (visible in the case of non-masculine nouns), cf. “pîrek-ê berê ji mêr nefret di-kir” [woman-OBL.F earlier from man hate PRS-do.PFV.SG] ‘The woman used to hate the man.’

Ask Nikita whether "ecibandin" is "tr" or "intr". We (NK + SS) agreed that in this case, we prefer the option with “ecibandin”, which obviously displays the TR pattern. Alternative is a translation using “hez kirin (tr)”: “zilam ji kiras-ê hez di-k-e” [man from shirt(F)-OBL.F love PRS-do.IPFV-3SG] ‘The man likes the shirt’, which displays the SBJ.TR_jiOBL pattern, see 46 for discussion.

Alternative is “şerm kirin (tr)” as in the sentence like “zilam ji dirêjbun-a xwe şerm di-k-e” [man from height-EZ.F self shame PRS-do.IPFV-3SG] ‘The man is shy about his own height.’. This sentence has not been obtained in the past tense environment, but probably it features the “SBJ.TR_jiOBL” pattern (if not the “SBJ.INTR_jiOBL” pattern).
